fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with images. Then every morphism of \mathcal { C } can be factored as a cover followed by a monomorphism. Moreover, this factorization is unique up to isomorphism in the sense that if A \twoheadrightarrow C \rightarrowtail B and A \twoheadrightarrow C' \rightarrowtail B are both cover-mono factorizations of the same morphism, then C \cong C'.

By the construction of images, every morphism f \colon A \to B can be factored as \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}, where \vartheta is the unit of the image adjunction. \mathsf { Img } (f) is monic by construction and \vartheta _{f} is a cover by .

To show the second half of the lemma, it suffices to show that every cover-mono factorization of a morphism f is isomorphic to \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Let hg be a cover-mono factorization of f. Then since \vartheta _{f} is a split epimorphism, there is a morphism s such that hs = \mathsf { Img } (f) and that s \vartheta _{f} = g. Then, it follows that s is monic.
Since g is extremal, s must be an isomorphism.
Let \mathcal { C } be a category with images. The underlying morphism of the unit \vartheta _{f} \colon f \to \mathsf { Img } (f) is an extremal epimorphism for all f \in { \mathcal { C } _{/ B }}.

An epimorphism f \colon A \twoheadrightarrow B is said to be extremal (also called a cover) if for any monomorphism m \colon C \rightarrowtail B and any morphism g \colon A \to C such that f = mg, then m is an isomorphism.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} admits a left adjoint \mathsf { Img } \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) for all objects A \in \mathcal { C }.

Let f \colon A \to B be a morphism in a regular category. Then for any two subobjects A' \rightarrowtail A and B' \rightarrowtail B, we have \exists _{f}(A' \cap f ^{*} (B')) \cong \exists _{f}(A') \cap B' in \mathsf { Sub } (B), where \exists _{f} is the left adjoint of f ^{*} constructed in .
By the construction of \exists _{f}, this is equivalent to showing the following isomorphism. \mathsf { Img } (f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B'))) \cong \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B'

By the pasting lemma, the back square is also a pullback. Then since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, the north edge of the back square is also a cover. The diagonal of the right face is \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B', which forms a cover-mono factorization of the composite f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B')). Thus, by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (f \circ (A' \cap f ^{*} (B'))) \cong \mathsf { Img } (f \circ A') \cap B' as required.

A category \mathcal { C } is regular iff it is cartesian and has images that commute with pullbacks, i.e., the following diagram commutes up to isomorphism for any object f \in { \mathcal { C } _{/ B }}.
